members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  According to the 11th Five-Year Plan, the Government of the People’s Republic of China 
(PRC) will prioritize the development of public transportation with mass rapid transit (MRT) as a 
key  transport  mode  in  mega  cities.  However,  limited  municipal  government  budgets  may 
constrain the development of MRT projects, which typically require substantial investments. As 
a result, the Government of the PRC has requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
provide  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  suggest  appropriate  public–private  partnership  (PPP) 
financing modalities for financing urban rail-based transportation systems.1 The advisory TA is 
consistent with the PRC Country Strategy and Program Update (2006–2008) dated 8 August 
2005, which supports innovative PPPs, especially in the provision of infrastructure. The fact-
finding mission that was conducted from 24 to 26 October 2005 reached an understanding with 
the Government on the TA objectives, scope, financing, implementation arrangements, and 
terms of reference. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2 Consistent with the 
Agreement Establishing ADB, the Government of the PRC will be requested to confirm that it 
has no objection to the proposed TA. No activities under the TA will commence and no TA 
consultant will be contractually engaged by ADB unless and until the Government no-objection 
has been attained. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Urbanization in the PRC has become an increasingly dominant phenomenon in recent 
years, with the urban population growing at a faster pace than the total population. It is forecast 
that the urban population in the PRC will increase from 536.0 million in 2005 to 694.4 million in 
2015, and to 827.0 million in 2025. The percentage of the urban population in the PRC is 
expected to rise from 40.5% in 2005 to 49.5% in 2015 and 57.2% in 2025. By comparison, the 
percentage of the urban population in the whole of Asia is forecast to be 45.5% in 2015 and 
51.4% in 2025. Currently, three out of the 30 largest urban agglomerations in the world are in 
the  PRC  and  there  are  23  cities  in  the  PRC  with  populations  over  2  million.3  Though 
urbanization could bring in benefits in terms of increasing economic activity, employment and 
income  generation,  poor  or  unorganized  urban  management  could  cause  negative 
consequences stemming from uncontrolled growth, environmental degradation, and inadequate 
social, transport, or other public services. Rapid motorization, traffic congestion and pollution 
have become common in many large cities in the PRC. The Government is therefore promoting 
the  development  of  public  transportation,  including  urban  rail  systems,  to  relieve  traffic 
congestion, reduce pollution, and enhance mobility for urban commuters. 
 
3.  Urban rail systems4 are currently operating in Beijing, Changchun, Chongqing, Dalian, 
Guangzhou, Nanjing, Shanghai, Shenzhen, Tianjin, and Wuhan, with a total length of 420 
kilometers (km). Many other large and medium-sized cities consider new or expanded MRT 
systems  the  backbone  of  their  integrated  transportation  network  plans.  Fifteen  cities  have 
proposed  building  MRT  systems  to  the  State  Council  as  part  of  their  urban  transport 
development plans.5 These MRT projects will involve the construction of 65 routes totaling 1,700 
km in length at a total investment cost of about CNY600 billion over the next decade.  
                                                 
1 In this TA paper, the terms “mass rapid transit (MRT)” and “urban rail” will be used interchangeably. MRT includes, 
for the purpose of this TA, light rails, metros, and trams. 
2 The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (internet edition) on 5 August 2005.   
3 United Nations. 2004. World Urbanization Prospects: The 2003 Revision. New York. 
4 Including metros, light rails, and railways that connect urban and suburban areas. 
5 Out of these 15 cities, seven—Chengdu, Guangzhou, Harbin, Hangzhou, Shanghai, Shenyang, and Shenzhen—
have already obtained approval from the State Council.

2     
4.  The preparation of an urban rail project requires multifaceted assessment not only in the 
context of overall urban and transport network development, but also in view of competing 
agendas,  which  call  for  systems  that  are  at  once  (i)  technically  efficient,  (ii)  financially 
sustainable,  and  (iii)  socially  fair  and  affordable.  Technically  efficient  systems  tend  to  be 
oversized and financially unviable without high fares, which are not deemed socially acceptable. 
Less expensive systems allow for lower fares, but might be technically suboptimal and increase 
the burden on the government budget. In the past, these conflicting goals have frequently led to 
implementation delays or selection of systems that, while less expensive, are inappropriate. 
Furthermore, there has been little evidence internationally that MRT projects can generate 
sufficient revenue from fares and other sources to cover both operation and maintenance and 
investment costs.6 While public budget funds can be utilized to finance investment in MRT, 
private sector participation would allow public budget funds to be used in other priority areas, 
such as education and social services, and enhance the operational efficiency of MRT systems. 
 
5.  In the PRC, the development of an urban rail transportation system must be included in 
a  city's  urban  transport  development  plan,  which  is  subject  to  review  by  the  National 
Development  and  Reform  Commission  (NDRC),  in  consultation  with  the  Ministry  of 
Construction,  before  being  submitted  to  the  State  Council  for  approval.  Once  the  urban 
transport development plan is approved, the municipal government must prepare a feasibility 
study of its urban rail project and submit it to NDRC for final approval. NDRC takes into 
consideration  certain  criteria,  such  as  gross  domestic  product,  fiscal  revenue,  fiscal 
management capability, and the investment track record of the municipality, in reviewing the 
feasibility study and determining an appropriate type for an urban rail. However, there is no 
meaningful  overview  of  the  financing  plan.  Once  the  feasibility  study  is  approved,  the 
municipality takes full responsibility for mobilizing finances for its project. Existing MRT systems 
in the PRC were financed by municipal government budgets, domestic bank loans, and foreign 
loans, mainly from export credit agencies. However, these traditional sources of financing will be 
inadequate for the massive funds required for the many MRT projects in the pipeline. Municipal 
governments are experiencing rising expenditure burdens as a result of the increasing urban 
population and higher demand for social services. Their revenues, which come mainly from 
land-use charges, local taxes, and fees, are insufficient to cover these rising expenditures.  
 
6.  To  relieve  the  extremely  heavy  burden  of  MRT  investments,  the  Beijing  municipal 
government has adopted a PPP modality for the construction of the Beijing No. 4 urban rail 
line.7 Shenzhen municipal government is also considering PPP financing for the expansion of its 
urban rail system. It is thus envisaged that PPP financing will play an important role for MRT 
financing  in  the  PRC.  Going  forward,  there  is  a  need  for  guidelines  to  evaluate  different 
financing alternatives, including PPP structures. Specific criteria to select concessionaires or 
private sector operators are also needed, as is a clear and transparent legal and regulatory 
framework to attract potential investors. Currently projects have to comply with a broad policy 
document that sets out general operational and safety requirements for urban rail systems, and 
other relevant laws such as contract law, foreign joint venture law, and urban planning law. 
However, neither PPP laws nor concession laws or regulations are in place.  
                                                 
6 World Bank. 2002. Cities on the Move: A World Bank Urban Transport Strategy Review. Washington, DC. It is 
estimated that investment for urban rail varies from $10 million to $30 million per km for light rail, to $30 million to 
$100 million per km for full heavy rail metros, the most expensive of which are fully automatic underground 
systems. Regarding the financial performance of select MRT systems, the revenue to operating cost ratio ranges 
from 0.42 in Kolkata, India to 1.84 in Santiago, Chile. 
7 The Beijing municipal government will bear infrastructure investment costs, while a project company owned by 
Beijing Capital Group, Beijing Infrastructure Investment Company, and Hong Kong MTR Corporation will invest in 
rolling stock.

3
7.  While  some  large  municipalities  have  experience  in  structuring  and  operating  MRT 
systems, many other municipalities will be implementing their first MRT projects. These will 
most likely be the largest single investments these cities have ever made. Due to a lack of 
experience  and  guidelines,  these  municipalities  are  struggling  to  come  up  with  financing 
schemes for these complex mega projects. A PPP manual or set of guidelines will thus serve as 
a useful tool during the project preparatory phase to assess different PPP modalities, which vary 
in  terms  of  return  and  risk  allocation  mechanisms  as  well  as  operational  and  financing 
arrangements. Municipalities will also have to look for alternative revenue sources to fund public 
transport projects—not only from property or other ancillary services related to MRT projects 
themselves, but also from expanded tax bases that cover both direct and indirect beneficiaries. 
 
8.  ADB has supported urban transport in the PRC before. Major lessons learned from an 
earlier  ADB  TA  on  Beijing  Urban  Transport  will  be  incorporated  into  the  implementation 
arrangement under this TA (para. 14).8 An important lesson from that TA is that it is vital to 
involve all relevant agencies in preparing multisectoral plans. In addition, key suggestions for 
planning MRTs suggested by a study on China Urban Transport Strategy sponsored by ADB 
and the World Bank in 1995 could be applicable in the current context.9 In the past ADB has 
also provided technical assistance to develop institutional capacity to promote private sector 
participation in the PRC. TA projects on build-operate-transfer (BOT) schemes in the water-
supply sector10 were rated as successful, and helped strengthen institutions dealing with the 
water supply.11 In the transport sector, ADB provided technical assistance to prepare guidelines 
and build the capacity of government officials to facilitate the application of the BOT modality 
corporatization, leasing, and securitization mechanisms to highway projects.12 Lessons learned 
from previous TA projects have been incorporated into the design of the proposed TA. Such 
lessons include the importance of establishing a steering committee to address inter-agency 
coordination issues, and the importance of publishing the TA findings in the local language.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The TA will aim to facilitate private sector investments, or PPP financing, for urban rail 
projects, and as a result contribute to enhancing mobility and reducing traffic congestion and 
pollution in urban areas of the PRC. The three pillars in the ADB-sponsored study Connecting 
East Asia: A New Framework for Infrastructure are (i) inclusive development, (ii) coordination, 
                                                 
8 ADB. 1997. Technical Assistance Completion Report on TA 2212-PRC: Beijing Urban Transport. Manila. The TA 
was designed in response to a request from the Government to provide a loan to extend line 1 of the Beijing metro 
but the Government subsequently indicated that it would not request further assistance from ADB to prepare a loan 
project. 
9 The study includes only limited analysis of financing alternatives because almost all MRT systems operating at that 
time were financed by public budget funds, while PPP financing was not widely prevailing. 
10 ADB. 1995. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China on the Seminar on Build-Operate-Transfer in 
the Water Supply Sector. Manila; and ADB. 1997. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China on Build-
Operate-Transfer Chengdu Water Supply. Manila. The latter TA led to the first BOT water supply project in the 
PRC awarded on a competitive basis and ADB made a private sector loan to the winning bidder, ADB. 1999. 
Chengdu  Generale  des  Eaux-Marubeni  Waterworks  Company  Limited.  Manila.  (Investment  1670-PRC,  for 
$21.5 million, approved on 11 February 1999). 
11 ADB. 2002. Technical Assistance Performance Audit Report on Urban Development Advisory Assistance to the 
People’s Republic of China. Manila. 
12 ADB. 2004. Technical Assistance Completion Report on TA 2649-PRC: Facilitating the Build-Operate-Transfer 
Modality in the Highway Sector. Manila; and ADB. 2003. Technical Assistance Completion Report on TA 2952-
PRC: Corporatization, Leasing, and Securitization in the Road Sector. Manila.

4     
and (iii) accountability and risk management.13 Taking into account those three pillars, the TA 
will (i) address the tradeoff between the financial sustainability of an MRT project and the 
affordability to users; (ii) deliver outputs based on consultative processes and coordination, both 
vertically  between  central  and  municipal  governments,  and  horizontally  between  various 
municipal  agencies  (such  as  those  covering  urban  management,  inter-modal  transport 
networks, and financing); and (iii) enhance transparency and accountability during the decision-
making process through the introduction of a PPP manual, which will clearly delineate return 
and risk allocation mechanisms and the responsibilities of the public and private sector under 
each PPP modality. Lessons learned from previous infrastructure projects implemented under 
ADB’s private sector operations highlight the importance of a conducive policy environment and 
a well-established regulatory framework to mitigate political and commercial risks.14 Moreover, 
in line with the ADB draft Transport Sector Strategy, the TA will represent ADB assistance at an 
early  stage  to  build  the  capacity  of  relevant  agencies  to  develop  MRT  systems,  and  will 
potentially lead to the first ADB-financed PPP urban rail project in the PRC.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will cover four key components: (i) summarizing international best practices and 
urban rail project case studies; (ii) modeling concession structures and alternative revenue 
sources,  and  suggesting  revisions  to  the  legal  and  regulatory  frameworks  to  facilitate  the 
application of PPP modalities; (iii) creating a PPP manual and organizing seminars and/or 
training sessions to apply the manual in practice; and (iv) recommending one or two pilot cities 
for further ADB financial assistance. 
 
11.   The first component will involve desk reviews of previous studies on PPP modalities and 
alternative revenue sources to finance existing urban rail projects in both the PRC and other 
developed and developing countries.15 In the past, fare-box revenues, development of real 
estate,  and  advertisement  along  MRT  lines  were  the  main  income  drivers  for  cities  with 
sustainable MRT systems, such as Hong Kong, which adopted a property model to enhance its 
financial viability. Little attention has been given to exploring how indirect beneficiaries, who 
experience  intangible  benefits  like  less  traffic  congestion  and  more  efficient  infrastructure 
services, can share the massive investment costs of MRT. The TA will look beyond project-
related  ancillary  revenues  and  consider  MRT  projects  in  the  broader  context  of  municipal 
financing (e.g., collection of taxes and/or fees from direct and indirect beneficiaries or bond 
issuance).  The  TA  will  study  funding  methods  for  public  transport  in  other  countries,  and 
suggest appropriate forms of alternative revenues, taking into account the existing legal and 
regulatory framework and consultative discussions with relevant agencies in the PRC.  
 
12.   To develop a PPP manual and/or practical guidelines in the context of the PRC, the TA 
will  seek  input  from  all  stakeholders,  including  the  central  and  municipal  governments, 
beneficiaries, investors, operators, suppliers, financiers, and potential users of MRT systems. 
Subsequently, the TA recommendations will be disseminated and the PPP manual explained to 
government officials in training sessions. Lastly, the multidisciplinary consulting team will review 
the feasibility studies of MRT projects in the pipeline, paying special attention to ridership 
forecasts and the technical, economic, and financial grounds for the proposed projects. Pilot city 
recommendations will be made based on this review.  
                                                 
13 ADB, The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development/The World Bank, Japan Bank for International 
Cooperation. 2005. Connecting East Asia: A New Framework for Infrastructure. Washington, D.C.  
14 ADB. 2001. Private Sector Operations: Strategic Directions and Review. Manila. 
15 Experience indicates that the BOT model may require adjustments to suit MRT projects. For example, reverse-
tender BOT, whereby bids are evaluated on the basis of the lowest public subsidy required, may be considered.

5
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $625,000 equivalent. ADB will finance $500,000 
equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The 
Government will finance $125,000 equivalent in-kind through the provision of office space, office 
equipment, in-city transportation, and counterpart staff, while secretariat and administrative 
support will be financed under the TA budget. The detailed cost estimate and financing plan are 
in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The Ministry of Finance (MOF) will be the Executing Agency of the TA, with technical 
support from NDRC. NDRC will provide technical advice and suggestions to a consulting team 
to be recruited under the TA, as well as logistical support and coordination with, especially, 
municipal governments. MOF will designate an individual to coordinate with the consultant and 
will  set  up  a  steering  committee  to  supervise  TA  implementation  at  the  policy  level.  It  is 
envisaged that the steering committee will consist of representatives from MOF, NDRC, the 
Ministry of Construction, and the municipal governments. The committee will discuss the TA 
outputs,  provide  feedback  to  the  consultant,  and  recommend  how  to  implement  the  TA 
recommendations in practice. MOF will assume the secretariat function of the committee. 
 
15.  The TA will be implemented by a consulting firm over a period of 18 months starting in 
May 2006 and ending in November 2007. The TA will engage 30 person-months of consulting 
services consisting of 10 person-months of international and 20 person-months of domestic 
consultants. The areas of expertise include PPP financing, municipal financing, relevant laws 
and regulations, and MRT technical expertise. The TA will involve multidisciplinary and complex 
consulting activities covering urban rail transport, PPP financing, municipal financing, and legal 
and regulatory aspects, and will require innovative approaches. Therefore, the quality-based 
selection method and full technical proposal will be used in recruiting the consultant. The firm 
will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by Asian 
Development Bank and Its Borrowers and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the 
engagement of domestic consultants. Outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3. 
 
16.  An inception report and detailed work plan will be submitted within 1 month of the 
commencement of the TA. The TA deliverables will first be discussed with the working-level 
staff, and subsequently with the steering committee, before being finalized. It is envisaged that 
the outputs under component A will be submitted within 4 months, and component B outputs will 
be submitted within 9 months. The PPP manual and recommendations of the pilot cities under 
the other two components will be finalized within 15 months of TA start-up. The final PPP 
manual and other key reports will be prepared in both English and Chinese and distributed to 
relevant agencies in both central and municipal governments. The seminars and/or training 
sessions will be organized within 3 months of the submission of the final version of the PPP 
manual. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Application of Public–Private Partnerships 
in Urban Rail-Based Transportation Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Review, analysis, and recommendations in this technical assistance (TA)  will focus 
primarily  on  policy,  regulatory,  legal,  contractual,  financial,  and  commercial  aspects  of 
developing  and  implementing  urban  rail-based  transportation  involving  private  sector 
participation or public–private partnership (PPP). Special attention will be given to concession 
structure; risk and return allocation; the roles of each project participant (government, investor, 
operator,  constructor,  financier,  etc.);  the  initial  capital  funding  structure  and  arrangement; 
revenue  generation  modalities;  provision  of  subsidies,  tax  concessions,  and/or  revenue 
guarantees; financing obligations of future capital investments and/or expansion; operation and 
maintenance arrangements; and government policies and regulatory framework. Concession 
structures  and  alternative  revenue  sources  will  be  designed  (i)  to  enable  a  municipal 
government (or a project) to realize additional revenues or reduce expenditures, (ii) to allow the 
project to make independent commercial decisions for operation and maintenance and for future 
capital investments, (iii) to provide incentives to increase ridership directly or indirectly so as to 
improve overall utilization of the projects, and (iv) to balance the financial and nonfinancial 
burden of the investment between direct and indirect beneficiaries. The TA will consist of the 
following four components.  
 
A.  International Best Practices and Case Studies  
2.  Component A will require 3 person-months of consulting services in the areas of PPP 
structure and urban rail-based transportation, comprising 1 person-month of international and 2 
person-months of domestic consultants to carry out the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Summarize international best practices in developing, structuring, and financing 
urban rail projects involving private sector participation or PPP in developed 
countries.  Present  various  cases,  highlight  the  key  factors  to  mobilize  and 
maximize the benefits of private sector involvement, and draw any lessons that 
might be applicable for developing member countries.  
 
(ii)  Present and analyze the development and implementation of urban rail projects 
involving  private  sector  participation  or  PPP  in  large  cities  in  Asia  such  as 
Bangkok,  Hong  Kong,  Kuala  Lumpur,  Manila,  and  Singapore.  Compare  with 
those in developed countries in point (i) above, and present any lessons learned 
from the Asian cases. 
 
(iii)  Conduct diagnostic analysis of urban rail projects that have been planned or are 
operating in the PRC with or without private sector participation. Additionally, 
analyze financing modalities and subsidy policies for such projects. 
 
(iv)  Assess the application of each case in points (i) and (ii) above in the context of 
the  PRC,  taking  into  account  the  findings  in  point  (iii)  above.  Analyze  and 
compare  various  aspects  of  the  cases  and  outline  the  advantages, 
disadvantages, and lessons learned from each case.

Appendix 3  11 
B.  Concession Structures, Alternative Revenue Sources, and Legal and Regulatory 
Framework 
3.  Component B will require 11 person-months of consulting services in the areas of PPP 
structure, municipal financing, and legal expertise, comprising 3 person-months of international 
and 8 person-months of domestic consultants to carry out the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Examine and summarize the structure of municipal revenues and expenditures 
as well as laws and regulations related to various financing modalities (e.g., 
public  budget,  private  sector  investments,  PPP  structure,  bond  or  equity 
issuance) for municipal infrastructure projects. 
 
(ii)  Identify any legal, regulatory, or institutional constraints to successful private 
sector participation or application of PPP structure in urban rail projects in the 
PRC, and suggest ways to remove such constraints. 
 
(iii)  Identify innovative concession structures and alternative revenue sources for 
urban rail-based transportation systems involving private sector participation or 
PPP in the PRC. Alternative revenue sources should aim to relieve the fiscal 
burden of municipal governments and enhance the private sector’s role in the 
sector, and will include not only ancillary revenues for specific projects (such as 
income from property development), but also taxes or fees that could potentially 
be  collected  from  both  direct  beneficiaries  (e.g.,  users  and  commuters)  and 
indirect beneficiaries (e.g., owners of motor vehicles benefiting from less traffic 
congestion).1 Taxes and fees might include environmental taxes on the use and 
ownership  of  cars  and  taxes  to  be  collected  from  enterprises  in  the 
municipalities.2  
 
(iv)  Recommend how the innovative concession structures and alternative revenue 
sources suggested in point (iii) above could be contractually realized in practice, 
taking into account legal and institutional frameworks in the PRC. 
 
C.  PPP Manual 
4.  Component C will require 9.5 person-months of consulting services in the areas of PPP 
structure, municipal financing, and relevant laws and regulations, comprising 3.5 person-months 
of international and 6 person-months of domestic consultants to carry out the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Review the findings and recommendations of previous studies related to the 
application of PPP in infrastructure financing in the PRC, including the following 
ADB TAs: TA2504-PRC: Seminar on Build-Operate-Transfer in the Water Supply 
Sector3,  TA2649-PRC:  Facilitating  the  Build-Operate-Transfer  Modality  in  the 
Highway Sector4, TA2804-PRC: Build-Operate-Transfer Chengdu Water Supply5, 
                                                 
1 The TA will also explore other relevant studies, such as collection of fuel tax and establishment of a fund to finance 
public transport in the PRC. 
2 Such taxes could be similar to a French Transport Tax (Versement Transport Tax), which requires employers with 
more than nine employees to contribute toward the cost of public transport investment and operations.  
3  ADB. 1995. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China on the Seminar on Build-Operate-Transfer in 
the Water Supply Sector. Manila. (TA2504-PRC), approved on 22 December 1995 for $100,000. 
4  ADB. 1996. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China on Facilitating the Build-Operate-Transfer 
Modality in the Highway Sector. Manila. (TA2649-PRC), approved on 27 September 1996 for $1,100,000.

12  Appendix 3 
and  TA2952-PRC:  Corporatization,  Leasing,  and  Securitization  in  the  Road 
Sector6. 
  
(ii)  Review the decision-making process for implementing urban rail projects in the 
PRC. To ensure synergies and consistencies in the deliverables, coordinate with 
the  consultants  under  TA4604-PRC:  Nanjing  Water  Utility  Long-term  Capital 
Finance in Commercial Markets (Cofinanced by the Cooperation Fund for the 
Water Sector)7; and the consultants to be recruited under the ADB TA on Study 
on Sustainable Urban Development in Metropolitan Regions;8 and the TA on 
Urban  Transport  Strategy  financed  by  the  World  Bank  and  the  Global 
Environment Facility.  
 
(iii)  Develop a manual to guide relevant authorities in: assessing the feasibility of 
urban rail projects involving private sector participation or PPP; understanding 
the  regulatory  and  legal  issues  that  need  to  be  addressed  to  successfully 
implement such projects; selecting an appropriate PPP structure with a fair risk–
return allocation among the project participants; implementing proper legal and 
contractual concessions in line with international best practices; and preparing 
projects  for  the  bidding  process.  Such  a  manual  should  cover  the  following 
topics, among others: 
 
(a)  methodology to conduct financial and economic analysis of urban rail 
projects;  
(b)  methodology to evaluate the impact of such projects on government 
budgets; 
(c)  criteria and indicators for the municipalities to evaluate different PPP 
structures, taking into account technical, financial, economic, and social 
aspects;  
(d)  clear delineation of responsibilities between the government and private 
operators or concessionaires under each PPP structure; 
(e)  bidding procedures and key criteria in selecting a private operator or 
concessionaire; 
(f)  revenue or return sharing and risk allocation mechanisms between the 
government and private operators or concessionaires; 
(g)  basis and factors to be considered for tariff setting;  
(h)  legal  issues  that  must  be  considered  when  drawing  up  concession 
agreements  and  other  legal  documents  governing  the  relationship 
between the government and the private operator or concessionaire; and 
(i)  description of different financing sources available for urban rail projects 
in the PRC (e.g., commercial banks, multilateral development banks, 
export  credit  agencies,  and  bond  or  equity  issuance),  and  their 
requirements. 
                                                                                                                                                          
 
5 ADB. 1997. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China on Build-Operate-Transfer Chengdu Water 
Supply. Manila. (TA2804-PRC), approved on 2 June 1997 for $600,000. 
6  ADB. 1997. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China on Corporatization, Leasing, and Securitization 
in the Road Sector. Manila. (TA2952-PRC), approved on 17 December 1997 for $1,000,000. 
7  ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China on Nanjing Water Utility Long-term Capital 
Finance in Commercial Markets (Cofinanced by the Cooperation Fund for the Water Sector). Manila. (TA4604-
PRC), approved on 28 June 2005. The ADB financing of $550,000 consists of $440,000 financed by the ADB’s TA 
funding program and $110,000 financed by the ADB Cooperation Fund for the Water Sector. 
8  Scheduled for approval in 2005.

Appendix 3  13 
The  PPP  manual  will  be  prepared  taking  into  account  deliverables  under 
components A and B, the reviews mentioned in points (i) and (ii) of para. 4 
above, and viewpoints from relevant stakeholders, such as central, provincial and 
municipal  governments,  private  sector  investors  and  financiers,  operators, 
suppliers, and potential users and other beneficiaries. 
 
(iv)  Recommend  a  coordination  mechanism  and  implementation  process,  with 
references to the PPP manual, for preparing, assessing, and implementing urban 
rail projects. 
 
(v)  Organize 1–2 day seminars and/or training sessions for relevant staff in the 
central and municipal governments to disseminate the findings and analysis of 
the TA and explain the application of the above PPP manual. The training should 
include several case studies of urban rail projects in Asia and the PRC. 
 
D.  Pilot City Selection 
5.  Component D will require a team of consultants with an understanding of different types 
of ADB financial assistance and experience in assessing feasibility studies and reviewing the 
operational and financial performance of urban rail projects. It is envisaged that component D 
will require 6.5 person-months of consulting services in the areas of PPP structure and MRT 
project preparation, comprising 2.5 person-months of international and 4 person-months of 
domestic consultants, to carry out the following tasks: 
(i)  Coordinate  with  relevant  central  and  municipal  governments  (including  the 
Ministry of Finance and the National Development and Reform Commission) to 
prepare a list of municipalities that have conducted feasibility studies or are in the 
process of preparing feasibility studies of urban rail projects, with the view of 
engaging private sector participation or financing under PPP. 
 
(ii)  Assess  the  validity  of  different  assumptions  under  such  feasibility  studies, 
including ridership forecasts, financial projections, and economic and technical 
grounds  for  proposed  urban  rail  modes  in  the  context  of  the  overall  urban 
transport  development  of  the  municipalities.  Review  economic  and  financial 
analysis, including financing plans, and highlight any issues or gaps that need 
work. 
 
(iii)  In consultation with the central government and ADB, recommend one or two 
pilot  cities9  to  be  further  explored  for  potential  financial  assistance  by  ADB. 
Justify such recommendations and identify issues to be studied in more detail for 
these potential projects. 
 
6.  The  consulting  firm  engaged  under  the  TA  will  have  broad  and  multidisciplinary 
experience relevant to the above activities. The team of consultants will be headed by a team 
leader who will manage the consultant inputs to produce the required outputs. An inception 
report and detailed work plan will be submitted within 1 month of TA commencement and will be 
                                                 
9 If two pilot cities are chosen, one should be from the large-city group that may have an urban rail system in place 
already, and the other should be from the medium-sized-city group that should be introducing a new urban rail.

14  Appendix 3 
presented to the steering committee10 to ensure their concurrence with the methodology, work 
plan, and implementation schedule. The outputs under component A will be submitted within 4 
months of TA start-up, and the outputs under component B will be submitted within 9 months of 
start-up. The consultants will then make a mid-term presentation to the steering committee, 
incorporating comments from both the steering committee and ADB. The draft PPP manual, 
pilot city recommendations, and other recommendations under components C and D will be 
discussed with relevant stakeholders and officials at the working level, then presented to the 
steering committee. The outputs under components C and D will be finalized within 15 months 
of TA commencement. The final PPP manual and other key reports will be prepared in both 
English and Chinese. The seminars and/or training sessions on the application of the PPP 
manual will be organized within 3 months of submission of the final version of the PPP manual.  
                                                 
10 The composition and functioning of the steering committee will be similar to the one set up to supervise the Urban 
Transport Development Project to be financed by the World Bank and the Global Environment Facility. It is 
expected that the two interventions will benefit from a shared knowledge base.
